paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere despite strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host star, and what are the constraints on its composition?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b Observation
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy across full orbital phase curve
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Earth-sized rocky exoplanet on tidally locked orbit around M dwarf star, observed with JWST MIRI to capture thermal phase variations and spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock No-atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Theoretical model assuming a bare rocky surface with no atmospheric layer, minimal heat redistribution, and immediate reradiation of stellar flux.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Retrieval model with greenhouse gas absorption
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model incorporating significant carbon dioxide absorption, testing whether the 15 um spectral band indicates presence of CO2-rich atmosphere.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmospheric model assuming oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative plausible atmospheric state.

major_limitations: Single-planet study does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets
Retrieval assumptions regarding circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors
Stellar variability and instrument systematics may bias weak spectral feature detection
Night-side observational constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in current dataset
Degeneracies remain between atmospheric composition, cloud/haze properties, and circulation assumptions
